Issues.Title: Expose withMacroTask
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
If one wants to define custom event handlers (like one on `document`) which interact with Vue instances or Vue reactive state, one should wrap it with `withMacroTask` to assure that any changes to the reactive state and flushing of the queue happens in the macro task and not micro task. Otherwise it can be possible that Vue starts changing DOM as a consequence of the reactive change even before the event propagates along original DOM tree.

The problem is that `withMacroTask` cannot be accessed currently.

### What does the proposed API look like?
`withMacroTask` could simply be exposed in a way that it can be imported. Or maybe made available at `Vue.withMacroTask`.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Duplicate presence of slot error when using children through a scoped slot.
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/jsotron5000/eywraw8t/464522/](https://jsfiddle.net/jsotron5000/eywraw8t/464522/)





### Steps to reproduce
Run the JSFiddle and open up dev tools.
You will see the Vue warning about duplicate default slots even though there is only one slot in the template.

### What is expected?
No warning when using child components slotted into a renderless component.

### What is actually happening?
A warning is displayed saying there are duplicate default slots when there is only one.

---
Here is another JSFiddle with a use case where this bug would occur:

https://jsfiddle.net/jsotron5000/eywraw8t/464242/


It is a renderless tabs component that works with another component (TabItem) which can be passed in through a slot.

The TabContainer component looks at the TabItem components and relays them to the parent component through a scoped slot.

The warning only displays when doing anything with the child vnodes inside the render function.

If you replace the children prop in the JSFiddle with just a hard coded array there is no warning.

Issues.Title: A Recommendation for the File Bundle System
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
The current mainstream front-end development frames like Vue, React and webpack would bundle all the CSS and JS files into a single HTML file for a one-page application. This is a feasible and good implementation for reduction of TCP requests as for HTTP 1.x with the HTTP pipeline closed (pipeline for HTTP 1.x is not a good practice as well due to its head-of-line blocking). However, as HTTP/2 becomes available and popular, the large bundled file will be a bottleneck of your product. Therefore, for lower latency of TCP requests in the HTTP/2 scenario, I think a more utility building approach is on demand.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Sorry that I'm not a professional in front-end development (I major in Internet and front-end development is my hobby), thus I could only provide my assumption and suggestion. Here I propose two possibly practical means. 
First, instead of a bundled file, you could divide the file into several smaller files and set the HTTP head with a sequence number for each of them to guarantee the correct order since the transportation of files with HTTP/2 is actually an "out-of-order outcome" structure. Besides, a gzip compression method is also recommended to diminish your bundled file. This way has some shortcomings that the server will be requested to decompress (this is viable) and reorganize (I am not sure whether there is some workable way) the divided files.
Second, instead of bundling the files, why not have a try just letting the static resources be (of course compression is always necessary)? I think with HTTP/2 and HTTP pipeline now usable things may totally change that bundling itself will become a worse practice.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "A Recommendation for the File Bundle System" (#9088)

Issues.Title: Vue catches errors while running Jest tests
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/chris-sorrells/vue-jest-console-error-bug](https://github.com/chris-sorrells/vue-jest-console-error-bug)

#### Relevant code added to scaffolding
- [https://github.com/chris-sorrells/vue-jest-console-error-bug/commit/abf6a4d00981ae6d13ed1969f5ec0340aec5d84d](https://github.com/chris-sorrells/vue-jest-console-error-bug/commit/abf6a4d00981ae6d13ed1969f5ec0340aec5d84d)

### Steps to reproduce
- Scaffold a new Vue project using `vue-cli`.  Use Jest for unit testing.
- Create a `mounted()` lifecycle hook in the HelloWorld.vue component.
- Within `mounted()`, directly manipulate the `msg` prop to cause Vue to generate an error.
- Run the default `example.spec.js` test using `npm run test:unit`.

### What is expected?
The test should fail due to the error generated when directly manipulating the `msg` prop.

### What is actually happening?
Vue catches the error and uses `console.error` to display it.  Because `console.error` does not fail Jest tests, the test pass despite the error thrown.

![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8070528/48666488-99b49280-ea88-11e8-8fa8-b6d54d3a5136.jpg)

---
The underlying problem is that Vue is trying to determine whether it is appropriate to catch and `console.error` an error or allow the error to remain uncaught based on if Vue believes it is in a browser. Unfortunately, because Jest emulates the browser environment, error handling does not function as intended and tests will succeed inappropriately.

A fix for this would be to also check whether Vue is in a Node environment before catching the error.  This would allow Jest tests to operate as intended, and maintain the behavior of error handling in the browser.

Another fix would be to re-throw the error if `process.env.NODE_ENV === "test"`.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Vue catches errors while running Jest tests" (#9083)

Issues.Title: VueSSRServerPlugin and non-entry asset
Issues.Body:
in the following VueSSRServerPlugin code:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/3d220a65de8740fbc7d354bbda1563f67ad0034f/packages/vue-server-renderer/server-plugin.js#L45-L57

I encounter a situation where I have two chunks with only **one entry chunk**, and this entry chunk has only **one entry file** (main.3019976de7acdf975dc2.js).

_stats.chunks_:
```
chunks: Array(2)
  0:
    entry: true
    files: ["main.3019976de7acdf975dc2.js"]
    id: 0
    initial: true
    names: ["main"]
    ...
  1:
    entry: false
    files: ["serverscript-5cc314c7e56e0fa8a25f.js"]
    id: 1
    initial: true
    names: ["serverscript"]
    ...
```

But `stats.entrypoints[entryName]` reports two entry assets for the main entry point.

_stats.entrypoints_:
```
entrypoints:
  main:
    assets: (2) ["serverscript-5cc314c7e56e0fa8a25f.js", "main.3019976de7acdf975dc2.js"]
    chunks: (2) [1, 0]
    ...
```
This make the test `if (entryAssets.length > 1) { ...` to fail (Error: Server-side bundle should have one single entry file. Avoid using CommonsChunkPlugin in the server config.)

I wondering you can add further filtering to eliminate assets located in non-entry chunk ?
eg.
```
entryInfo.assets.filter( (asset, index) => stats.chunks[entryInfo.chunks[index]].entry )
```
returns: ["main.3019976de7acdf975dc2.js"]

is it relevant?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VueSSRServerPlugin and non-entry asset" (#9074)

Issues.Title: Improve vue-router's screen reader experience
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
This feature request is about the screen reader experience of apps built with vue-router. In a nutshell: When a user of assistive technology, such as a screen reader, activates a `<router-link>`, their focus stays on said link, giving them no feedback at all (user with sight don't have that problem because they see that parts of the app change). So it is about notifying user of DOM changes.

One way is to set the focus to the newly loaded content.

General links on this:
[](url)
* [Google's A11ycasts episode #22 on focus management in SPAs](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=srLRSQg6Jgg)
* [How to deal with the same problem in Angular](https://simplyaccessible.com/article/spangular-accessibility/#acc-heading-3)
* [Reach Router for React take on focus management in routers](https://reach.tech/router/accessibility)

My suggestion on this to match Reach Router behavour (which puts, after route transition, the focus on the wrapper of the loaded components. In my understanding the vue-router counterpart for this is `<router-view>`).

You could also go even further by defining a "focus target". I wrote about this approach here: https://marcus.io/blog/accessible-routing-vuejs

### What does the proposed API look like?
```
<router-view focustarget="someRefInChildComponent"></router-view>
// If focustarget is not supplied, focus after route transition is put on router-view itself
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Improve vue-router's screen reader experience" (#2488)

Issues.Title: Vue-router removes string after the special character from query
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/zxxwvypmmm](https://codesandbox.io/s/zxxwvypmmm)





### Steps to reproduce
Click to link **Link to test#123**

You will be prompted in the CodeSandbox browser bar: `?q=test#123`

But in `$router.query.q` to be added only `test`, then you will see on page:  *Query object { "q": "test" }*


### What is expected?
I would like to see in `$router.query.q` that object: `{q: 'test%23123'}`, that is so, special character # is converted to %23).

### What is actually happening?
After the `#` character, the rest of the line is removed.

---
I tried to solve the problem using `stringifyQuery` option. I created something like:
```
stringifyQuery: function (query) {
    const qs = require('qs')
    const result = qs.stringify(query, {encoder: (str) => str.replace(/#/g, '%23')})

    return result ? (`?${result}`) : ''
}
```
But this unfortunately doesn't work and still drops everything after character `#`. Why does the `vue-router` remove all characters in the query after `#`? Is there a way to undo this?

Sorry, that duplicate my issue #2485, which automatically closed by bot.

Issues.Title: 使用history模式，且在路由最后配置了通配页面，在ie9及以下会一闪而过。
Issues.Body:
使用history模式，在路由中配置了通配页面404，即在路由的最后添加
   {
      path:'*',
      name:'404',
      component:noPage
    }
这个时候在ie9下，访问已存在的页面，这个时候就会闪一下这个页面，然后才是匹配上的页面。
根据我的初步观察，因为ie9及以下不支持history模式，所以会自动转换成hash模式，但是这个时候路由已经进行匹配，所以找不到页面，转换完成后又进行了二次匹配所以，这个时候页面显示正常。
这个过程进行的很坑，如果不是我的电脑反应迟钝，还真无法发现这个问题。

Issues.Title: Inconsistent formatting with URL for named child route with no path and query params
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[http://jsfiddle.net/u3be49g0/](http://jsfiddle.net/u3be49g0/)





### Steps to reproduce
Open the JSfiddle and click the /user/foo link

### What is expected?
The URL should be /user/foo?test=test_param

### What is actually happening?
The URL is /user/foo/?test=test_param

---
This is a valid URL and the query property of $route still works, but the formatting is inconsistent with how query params are handled with other routes in vue router. This occurs only for named child routes with no path since it will automatically append the trailing slash (see https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/issues/1273).

Maybe this is intended, but it would be nice if query params were handled the same for all routes.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Return values from mutation commits.
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
One often wants to get the id of a created object back from the data store. Much like in a database, if you add an object to an array in the store, you want to get it's id so that you can reference it again. When looking up how to do this, I found that you cannot, and I also found that someone else had the exact same inquiry on stackoverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42404925/return-value-from-vuex-mutation-id-for-newly-created-object#42406872
The response to the question on stack overflow was to use vuex actions, but I don't think that one should have to use an asynchronous action to achieve a synchronous task.
To carry on with the database example, one might use postgresql's "RETURNING" as an analogy. One can perform an insert statement and then say RETURNING thing_id to get the automatically generated id, or whatever other fields they would like.

### What does the proposed API look like?
```
let myReturn = this.$store.commit('ADD_THING",{"name":"new_thing"});
// 'ADD_THING' adds a thing to an numerically indexed object and then returns the number.
console.log(myReturn); // {"id":42,"datestamp":1541145883085}
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Getters stop to work in routes under keep-alive after registerModule call
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/Alendorff/vue-vuex-getters-bug](https://github.com/Alendorff/vue-vuex-getters-bug)





### Steps to reproduce
* You have vuex store with static module
* You need to register a new vuex module on vue-router beforeEnter hook
* Your `router-view` is under `keep-alive`
* Your components related to different routes have getters mapped to static module
* Bug: when you enter route which should register new vuex module, getters from static module become broken.
Reactivity doesn't work - components with mapped getters do not receive updates.

### What is expected?
Getters should work

### What is actually happening?
Getters reactivity is broken. Components have stale getters values.

---
```
 "dependencies": {
    "vue": "2.5.17-beta.0",
    "vue-router": "^3.0.1",
    "vuex": "^3.0.1"
  }
```

Windows 10, Chrome Version 69.0.3497.100 (Official Build) (64-bit)

P.S. Not really sure if I should put this issue into the vuex repository, so pls tell me if there are better place for it.
